speaker: PUCK
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: SCENE I. Before LEONATO'S house.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: comes this night to Messina.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: when I left him.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But few of any sort, and none of name.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: home full numbers. I find here that Don Peter hath

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Much deserved on his part and equally remembered by

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: promise of his age, doing, in the figure of a lamb,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: bettered expectation than you must expect of me to

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: tell you how.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: glad of it.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I have already delivered him letters, and there

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: appears much joy in him; even so much that joy could

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: not show itself modest enough without a badge of

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: bitterness.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Did he break out into tears?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: In great measure.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: truer than those that are so washed. How much

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: wars or no?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: in the army of any sort.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What is he that you ask for, niece?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: O, he's returned; and as pleasant as ever he was.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool, reading

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath he

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: but he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath an

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: excellent stomach.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And a good soldier too, lady.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a lord?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: honourable virtues.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: It is so, indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: but for the stuffing,--well, we are all mortal.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: between them.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: conflict four of his five wits went halting off, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: now is the whole man governed with one: so that if

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: bear it for a difference between himself and his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath left,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: companion now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Is't possible?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: next block.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No; an he were, I would burn my study. But, I pray

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: you, who is his companion? Is there no young

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! if

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: thousand pound ere a' be cured.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I will hold friends with you, lady.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Do, good friend.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: You will never run mad, niece.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, not till a hot January.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Don Pedro is approached.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: cost, and you encounter it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort should

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow abides

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: and happiness takes his leave.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: is your daughter.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Her mother hath many times told me so.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: what you are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: herself. Be happy, lady; for you are like an

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: honourable father.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: like him as she is.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Benedick: nobody marks you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Is it possible disdain should die while she hath

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: in her presence.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: am loved of all ladies, only you excepted: and I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: heart; for, truly, I love none.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: A dear happiness to women: they would else have

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that: I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: swear he loves me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so some

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: gentleman or other shall 'scape a predestinate

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: scratched face.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Scratching could not make it worse, an 'twere such

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a face as yours were.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: so good a continuer. But keep your way, i' God's

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: name; I have done.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That is the sum of all, Leonato. Signior Claudio

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the least a month; and he heartily prays some

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To DON JOHN

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Please it your grace lead on?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Is she not a modest young lady?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: my simple true judgment; or would you have me speak

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: praise, too brown for a fair praise and too little

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: for a great praise: only this commendation I can

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: afford her, that were she other than she is, she

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: were unhandsome; and being no other but as she is, I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: do not like her.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: truly how thou likest her.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Would you buy her, that you inquire after her?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Can the world buy such a jewel?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting Jack,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man take

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you, to go in the song?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: looked on.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: matter: there's her cousin, an she were not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: as the first of May doth the last of December. But I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Shall I never see a bachelor of three-score again?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Go to, i' faith; an thou wilt needs thrust thy neck

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sundays. Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Re-enter DON PEDRO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What secret hath held you here, that you followed

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: not to Leonato's?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: man; I would have you think so; but, on my

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance. He is

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: in love. With who? now that is your grace's part.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Mark how short his answer is;--With Hero, Leonato's

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: short daughter.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If this were so, so were it uttered.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Like the old tale, my lord: 'it is not so, nor

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: 'twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should be

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: so.'

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: should be otherwise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my troth, I speak my thought.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That I love her, I feel.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That she is worthy, I know.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: That I neither feel how she should be loved nor

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at the stake.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: of beauty.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And never could maintain his part but in the force

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: of his will.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: brought me up, I likewise give her most humble

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in my

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: all women shall pardon me. Because I will not do

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: right to trust none; and the fine is, for the which

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with love than I will get again with drinking, pick

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and hang me

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: blind Cupid.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: wilt prove a notable argument.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped on

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the shoulder, and called Adam.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, as time shall try: 'In time the savage bull

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: doth bear the yoke.'

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns and set

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: them in my forehead: and let me be vilely painted,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and in such great letters as they write 'Here is

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: good horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: 'Here you may see Benedick the married man.'

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I look for an earthquake too, then.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, you temporize with the hours. In the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him I will

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: great preparation.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I have almost matter enough in me for such an

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: embassage; and so I commit you--

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To the tuition of God: From my house, if I had it,--

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the guards are but slightly basted on neither: ere

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you flout old ends any further, examine your

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: conscience: and so I leave you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: My liege, your highness now may do me good.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: No child but Hero; she's his only heir.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, my lord,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: When you went onward on this ended action,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That liked, but had a rougher task in hand

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Than to drive liking to the name of love:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Have left their places vacant, in their rooms

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Come thronging soft and delicate desires,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: All prompting me how fair young Hero is,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Thou wilt be like a lover presently

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And tire the hearer with a book of words.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And I will break with her and with her father,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: How sweetly you do minister to love,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That know love's grief by his complexion!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But lest my liking might too sudden seem,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The fairest grant is the necessity.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Look, what will serve is fit: 'tis once, thou lovest,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And I will fit thee with the remedy.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I know we shall have revelling to-night:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I will assume thy part in some disguise

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And take her hearing prisoner with the force

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And strong encounter of my amorous tale:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Then after to her father will I break;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: In practise let us put it presently.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt
